utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I’m okay. Let’s just go home.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: You’re getting checked out.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I tripped on the ice. Eight other kids tripped. This is embarrassing.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: You said you were just going to hang with your friends. I turn around and you’re out there on the ice.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I’m fine.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: You don’t know that. You fell. Awkwardly.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: No, I didn’t.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: You don’t know how to fall.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I’m sixteen. I’ve been falling a lot. I think I’m getting the hang of it. And I checked.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: And now the doctors are going to check.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: You don’t think that you’re over reacting? I don’t need you to fix every boo-boo.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: Then stop getting them.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I was just playing around with my friends. I was having fun.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: You know you can’t do that.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Oh, I can’t have fun?

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: You know what I mean. I’m gonna have a talk with your friends.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: And tell them that they need to stop…

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: No! I don’t want you freaking them out! Fine. Fine, we’ll go to the hospital. But they’re going to tell you that I’m fine and they’re going to tell you that you don’t need to worry about…

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Mom? Mom! Hello? Mom, you gotta wake up. No one’s coming. Mom!

utterance.speaker: Operator
utterance.content: 911. What’s your emergency?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: We got into an accident on the canal road just outside Kingston. My mom’s unconscious.

utterance.speaker: Operator
utterance.content: Are you all right?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I’m fine. Mom. Mom.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where’s Foreman?

utterance.speaker: Wendy
utterance.content: He’s down here somewhere.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Somewhere. Very helpful.

utterance.speaker: Wendy
utterance.content: Do you have any idea when he’s getting out tonight?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sometime.

utterance.speaker: Wendy
utterance.content: I realize you can’t predict. I just thought you might be able to estimate. It’s Valentine’s Day. I’ve planned a surprise getaway.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Getaway.

utterance.speaker: Wendy
utterance.content: Mmm-hmm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Getaway. Get away.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Is my mom okay?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s gone to surgery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Foreman. Your girlfriend wants to know if you’re available for Valentine’s. Act surprised. What are you doing down here?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There’s a snowstorm. E.R.’s short staffed. We’re all supposed to be here. You’re supposed to be here. You’re an ass. Act surprised. This could sting a little.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Ow. Can we hurry this up?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Make sure that …

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Take your time. What’s your name?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Hannah Morgenthal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have CIPA, Hannah Morgenthal.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: No, I don’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We have to do x-rays to make sure you don’t have internal injuries. Blood test to make sure no infections. An EEG for neurological anomalies and biopsy a spinal nerve.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Whoa, whoa. Congenital Insensitivity to Pain is one of the rarest conditions on the planet. There’s only been about sixty documented cases.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, and I have seven reasons to think that she’s one of them.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She says she’s not.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And that’s reason number one. She knew what it was without us telling her. Two, she’s still went from the snow but she’s not shivering. That’s odd. Unless she can’t sweat or feel hot and cold.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: The ambulance was warm. I want to see my mother.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Three, scarring around the lip and tongue. When she was a baby she chewed on herself without feeling it.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I fell through a window when I was a kid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Four, when you cleaned the wound she flexed into the cleaner instead of away from it. It’s hard to fake pain when you’ve never felt it. Takes an imaginative leap, Ms. Morgenthal. That’s one of them Jew names. Ashkenazys are a higher risk group.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: On the other hand, she says she doesn’t have it. And she’d be dead by now if she’d never been diagnosed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They killed our Lord. Are you going to trust them? She wants to see her mom. If she admits having CIPA she knows we’re not letting her go anywhere without a battery of tests.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You said you had seven reasons.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I pulled a number out of the air. What, five isn’t enough?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Five lame reasons aren’t. I’m taking her to see her mom as…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I could hit her again if six aren’t enough. Do the tests.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Need to bail on the E.R. I got a case. Why are you wearing perfume?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Is this a real case or one of those imaginary cases that happen when you’re bored?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: CIPA.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: CIPA is a diagnosis. Diagnoses happen at the end of cases.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s got no idea what’s going on in her body. There’s gotta be something wrong.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: In other words, she could be perfectly healthy but you’re curious about someone who can’t feel pain because you always feel pain so you want to go exploring.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She was in a car accident. She needs x-rays, blood tests, EEG, nerve biopsy. I also note that, although the snow was coming down in sheets this morning, you left your hat at home and used ear muffs.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do your tests, except for the…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, while everyone else was just worrying about getting in, you were concerned with about “hat head.” Blind dates are never a good idea. Only reason to wear a scarf like that is as a beacon to identify you in a crowd.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do your tests. Except for the nerve biopsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need the nerve biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’d risk paralyzing her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But it’s neurological.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You have no evidence of that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She tripped.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do you have any evidence other than the fact that a typically clumsy CIPA patient tripped on an icy day? If the EEG reveals a problem, we can talk then.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You could have left the scarf at home and just told him you’d be wearing a look of desperation.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Spiking on leads C3 and O2.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She could be going into a seizure.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Hello!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I think there’s a simpler explanation.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: You’re not going to find anything. I’m fine. I wanna see my mom.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, sedate her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She won’t consent.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s a teenager.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No dad, mom’s still in surgery. What do you want us to do? Hold her down?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, only until you inject her with a sedative. Then you can let her go.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We tried.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seriously?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s strong and doesn’t care. We’d have broken something before we could get her to sit still enough to inject her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, break her arm. She won’t mind.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re cranky.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m in pain. Let’s go break her arm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nurse Shortie, your biz-nitch, how long are you gonna waste her time.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m so glad we’re walking somewhere. Another sixty feet and this conversation is over.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When you guys are out of this program, Cameron will find somebody. Chase will find eight somebodies. And you’ll be alone.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Thirty feet.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ll date and you’ll date. But you’re the ultimate Darwinian. You’ve got to fight for everything. Anybody else would just slow you down.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m still with her, aren’t I?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. I can only imagine it’s because she hasn’t given you an excuse to break up and you don’t have the guts to recognize your own reality.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I want to see my mother.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hi again. I'm sure I can say this without being condescending, but then you'd get the false impression that I respect you so – you're a kid, you're scared, you're stalling. Grow up.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I'm not scared. I'm never scared.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See? How juvenile was that? You can't feel pain. Nothing left but pleasure. Why don't you tell me how wonderful that is?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: It sucks.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Better than being in pain all the time. Get in the chair.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Every morning I have to check my eyes to make sure I didn't scratch a cornea in my sleep.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh God, stop. I'm in a pool of tears here.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I can't cry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Neither can I. Every morning I check my eyes for jaundice in case the Vicodin's finally shot my liver.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I can't run anywhere without examining all my toes for swelling.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can't run.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Boys can't hold me for too long because I can overheat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Girls can't hold me for too long because I only pay for an hour.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I need an alarm on my watch to remind me to go to the bathroom. You know how many humiliating experiences before I thought of that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The bathroom's 50 feet from my office. Every drink of water I weigh the pros and cons,

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: After everything I do, I self-check: Mouth, tongue, gums for cuts. Count teeth, check temperature. Fingers, toes and joints for swelling, skin for bruises.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I got shot.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I sat on the stove when I was three. Want to see the coil marks?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: You think I’m lying?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think I just wanna check out your tuchus, as your people would say. Put her in the chair and run the damn test. If she moves again, give her nitrous.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You weren't shot because of leg pain, you were shot because you're a jerk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Some think the two are connected.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: He didn’t have to do that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, he did.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I’m sick?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, your EEG was normal. X-rays showed no breaks, blood test showed no infections, urine indicated no… Hannah? Call a code. Oh, God. Need ice packs and cooling blankets. Got saline in there?

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: She’s not flushed. She’s not sweaty. You must be…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She has a temperature of 105.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow. She’s actually sick.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’ve got her temperature down below boiling. Could be infection.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. LP showed normal proteins and no white blood cells.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: High billirubin. Could be a liver problem.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. Transaminases were normal.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be drugs. She’s smoked pot since she was eleven.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No again. Tox screen was clean.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’re doing this case backwards. We do the tests and then she gets sick?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maybe we did something to her. Maybe she got sick after the tests. We should rerun them.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And biopsy a spinal nerve.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You want to risk paralysis because she’s got a fever?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want to risk paralysis because I don’t know what’s causing the fever. If it’s neurological…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s a fever.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In a CIPA patient. Obviously things are a little different in her upstairs wiring.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And have been since the day she was born.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yah. It’s much more likely that whatever it is was cleverly waiting and hiding until you guys were done testing.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re all against this, right? And, you’re all going to stand on principle and refuse to do it, right? I’m going to get Cuddy’s approval.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How long are we going to keep Hannah in the dark about her mother?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Long as possible.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Side air bag should be standard.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m sure she’ll agree.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She should know her mother’s situation.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Breaking that news is that surgeon’s problem.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Any word from House?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Maybe Cuddy will say no.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Cuddy never says no.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s not true.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Nobody ever says no. We don’t say no.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You don’t say no.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He’ll come back. He’ll browbeat us. He’ll give us seven reasons and eventually we’ll fold. We all will. Not just me. The only way we can avoid biopsying this kid’s spine is to find the answer some other way.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: All the tests were negative.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We need a better history.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How much more paperwork do you need? We’ve got pediatric records, a few dozen E.R. records, our own admission questionnaire.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What’s the first question?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Insurance coverage.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Okay. Second question.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Just make your point.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Where does it hurt? If we knew where it hurt, we could diagnose her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You do know CIPA means she can’t feel pain.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No. CIPA means she’s insensitive to pain. She still has scattered nerve fibers that could conduct pain but the signals don’t make it to the brain. What if we give her more pain signals? A lot more pain signals. Maybe some of them might get through.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You want to torture her?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No. Yes, we do this to anybody else, it’s torture. Doing it to her, it’s no different than pricking her finger. We keep poking sharp sticks into her, eventually we’ll find the part that’s already tender.

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: So, what does a dean of medicine do?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, can we please not talk about that. I will talk about anything else, but I’m just trying to get away from work.

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: Metaphorically. Because, geographically the coffee place around the corner from the hospital probably isn’t the furthest you could get.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well the snow.

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: Roads are clearing. But it’s a good place to beat a retreat from. Do you usually expect your dates to go wrong?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Experience has taught me to have an escape route.

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: Well, low expectations, that’s in my favor.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Whatever happens, I need you to understand that there are certain aspects to my life, I’m not happy about.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need the nerve biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And you had to come here personally to tell me that. And how did you even know I was here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I had to bring the file. This is the most noncommittal location within walking distance. You left your car keys on your desk. Greg House. You two must have met online. Either that or you’ve got a friend who secretly hates you.

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: Uh, Don Herrick. Yeah, we connected through singleballroomdancelovers.com.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why would he volunteer that information?

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: Why would I hide it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You didn’t tell him that anything he said will be held against you? So, what line of work are you in?

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: Uh, auto maintenance. Changing oil and filters.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great, my place overcharges. You can’t trust anything you guys say. So, where are you located?

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: In fourteen states. I own Eastern Lube.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Most CIPA complications are infection and she’s got a fever. LP? Urine?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Clean. Normal. Same with the white blood cell count.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Cancer?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing on the scan. I think it’s her nerves messing with the temperature control. Amyloid, sarcoid, there’s a lot of candidates. I want a biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fine. If that’s what you need, go get it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He seems a lot nicer than that one from Wicca needs a daddy figure dot com.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: One of these is warm and the other is very hot. Start here. Move to the hot one, just a few second. Then back. We’re gonna monitor activity in your brain while you do it. If you feel any response to the heat, it could indicate a vascular problem.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: How’s my mom doing?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s okay. Do you feel anything?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: No. What does “okay” mean?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s still in surgery. They tell me it’s going okay. You can take your hand out.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: And you didn’t ask anything else?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Take your hand out of the water!

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: What’s going on with my mother?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hannah. You just got second degree burns.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I’ll be fine. What’s going on with my mother? Is she gonna die?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: They said she’s okay. Surgery this long is typical when there are internal injuries.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Naloxone and kinase proteins in.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: And that’s gonna make me feel pain? I didn’t feel anything when you guys screwed this thing into my head.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: They’ll replace missing chemicals in your nerves. Heightened sensitivity. We’re going to be drilling directly into your skull. A response should indicate sarcoma.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: What does it feel like?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It…hurts. Um…sorry. Bone pain is the worst there is. You need to let me know as soon as you feel anything. She’s ready.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: So, what? I just sit here while you guys drill a hole in me? You wanna talk?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Just you and your mom, huh? You two must be pretty close.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: We were. Until I got arrested. The third time.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Drugs?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Fights.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You got an advantage.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Not really. Never know when to stop.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You piss a lot of people off or you just trying to piss off your mom? Those are pretty much the only two choices you have. Hannah? You want us to stop? Stop the drill. Stop the drill! It’s okay. What’d you feel? Where did you feel it? Hannah, I need to know how it hurt. Hannah!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I am so tired of this. Did you know that the new nurse from cardiology is sleeping with that weird lawyer from the board?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The guy with eleven fingers?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He has eleven fingers?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How do you not notice that?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The nurse used to be a man.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s not anymore?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: But we can’t talk about that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I thought we were.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We were supposed to talk about that. I came here to talk about that. But on the way up, I ran into Cameron. You’ve got a CIPA patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mmmm. Tranny nurse is more interesting.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh it’s way more interesting. But instead, I’ve got to be your damn conscience. I'm tired of being your conscience. I don't enjoy being your conscience.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No one enjoys—

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're studying her....

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s actually sick.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Which you found out after you took her on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was curious. Since I'm not a cat, that's not dangerous.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I don't think that metaphor was designed to actually warn cats. You don’t care about her illness, you care about CIPA. Which means your focus is going to be on getting your answer, not hers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank you. Forewarned is forearmed.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What do you think you’re going to figure out? You think her lack of pain is somehow the answer to your pain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think if you’d stop talking to Cameron then right now we could be ranking nurses in order of doability.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Need you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What did the nerve biopsy show?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Never did it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well then, do it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Can’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s going to jump off the lobby balcony.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And you think I can catch her?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Get away from me.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not going to hurt you.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Yes you are. You’re just jealous that I can do anything.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Hannah, you’re having a paranoid delusion.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I don’t believe you.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Think she would?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: This is real. You want me to be in pain. You even said so.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If we wanted to hurt you, we’d let you jump.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Just let me see my mother.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Fine. We’ll take you to her OR observation room.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I don’t believe you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your mother is fine. I just spoke to her surgeon.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I don’t believe you.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hannah! What do you want from us? What do you want us to do?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I can’t feel my legs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re trying to pull the same stunt in ten minutes.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I’m not pretending. They don’t hurt, they’re just not there.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Anything? We’re not looking for pain. Anything at all? Pressure?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You have six broken bones, a fever, a concussion, erratic heart rhythms and a complete lack of sensation below the waist.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I feel fine. Is my mother out of surgery yet?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Not yet.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is excellent.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The paranoia seems to have dissipated but her vitals keep getting worse. She could be dead in hours.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But if you’re going to die a miserable, lingering death, pain free is the way to do it. Are we sure the fall didn’t cause the paralysis?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The paralysis caused the fall. Spine’s clean. No veritable fractures or spinal cord compression.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Even better. The nuttiness and paralysis means there’s definitely a neurological component.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be a nerve disease.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which is why we need to look at the nerve that you didn’t biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There are other tests…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: HIV? Syphilis? She was negative for all STDs. Vascular? No, ANA was negative. Cerebral clot? No, MRI was…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Thyroid storm.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Makes sense given her glucose reation was slow and her potassium is down.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. I’ll check with an endocrinologist.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Bennett’s on call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Perfect.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Nooooo.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Need a consult.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I already okayed your nerve biopsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need an endocrinologist.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Bennett’s on call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Won’t pick up. His cell phone must be broken.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Mine’s working.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Had to give you the file.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I assume you’re thinking thyroid storm. You done a hormone panel?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Normal. TSH was on the low side. Is that a cheery fire I hear crackling nearby?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No. What about CPK enzymes?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Elevated. 275. Of course, people light fires for themselves. But then they don’t deny it. He’s here.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: CPK isn’t high enough. Potassium’s what you’d expect because of the bronchodilators.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh my God. You’re not wearing a bra.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s not thyroid storm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You just met him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I like him. And I like sex. Do I need to stitch a letter on my tops?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. But it might be worth taking out an ad in the local papers.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do you like me, House? I was on the phone with Bennett 15 minutes ago. His cell phone’s working. You’re M.O is to avoid me at all costs. And suddenly you need my input on every move you make. I can only assume it’s because I’m on a date.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When we met, I noticed…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You noticed he was a Shriner because of the way he parted his hair. You noticed he was a momma’s boy because of the way he blinked his left eye. I’m not interested. I’m not impressed. There are only two reasons anyone would want to screw with me tonight. Either they’re an altruistic, decent person who’s worried about my well being. Or, they want me for themself.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You left out the third option. Evil bastard who just wants to mess with other people’s happiness.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Goodnight House. We won’t be bothered again.

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: It’s late. I should go.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: I part my hair on the left and I’m a Shriner?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You heard the conversation. I’m not interested in him.

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: I don’t blame you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I only said those things so he wouldn’t come back.

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: I don’t really care about my job. I do it well. I provide a service. But my goal was always to make enough money to do the things I really like. Music. Travel.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I like those things too.

utterance.speaker: Don
utterance.content: You like them but they’re not really important to you. I don’t know whether it’s House, your job or if you just thrive on conflict but… You should hear yourself when you’re talking to him. Nothing else in the world’s going on. You’re focused, confident, compelling. Don’t… don’t take this the wrong way, but I’d like to go out with that woman.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I can get her on the phone.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Where did you go? She’s getting worse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not thyroid storm. Get me a spinal nerve.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There are still other tests.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She just said the girl’s getting worse. You really want to wait?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’ll be risking infection. Maybe make the paralysis worse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It is worse. We’re making it worse than worse? Do the biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You could paralyze her and get no useful information.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do the biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re thinking peripheral neuropathy. We should take a nerve a little further away from the spine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A little further from the truth. We’re talking paralysis. Good chance the spine is relevant. This thing is progressing. It could kill her in hours. Give me back my papers.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Is he asking for a spinal nerve?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How did you know?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Give us a minute? Did you know they recently found a protein that speeds up nerve growth? Fascinating stuff. If you put that protein with the insulation from a spinal nerve, you could grow your own little garden. If that spinal nerve…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. If it happened to come from a person with CIPA I could grow pain-free nerves and graft them into my own leg. What an evil plan.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’d have to be on immunosupressors for life. Risk of infection. Shorter life span…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shorter, but normal.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Usually jealousy expresses itself by trying to destroy what someone has. You’re more ambitious. You actually want to change medical fact to get this thing you…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Medical fact changes all the time.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re risking your patient’s life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s how medical fact changes. A doctor risks…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: To serve their patient health, not their own.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is medically justified.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Are you sure? Are you sure that you’re the right one to be making this call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Biopsy whatever nerve you figure you can safely get at. God, Wilson’s annoying.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Past 3 a.m. on Valentine’s Day night. I assume you had a date with Wendy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’ll survive. She knows the deal.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re lucky.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Someday, when there's time, I would like to actually have a social life.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Someday? Come on. If there's one thing a good-looking woman can have whenever she wants, it's a social life.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You mean a sex life.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There's nothing wrong with a little companionship 'til the real thing comes along.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I had the real thing. Forgive me if I don't want to settle.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What does that mean?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You think I didn't have the real thing?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I have no idea what you had.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And yet you're judging it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's late. I'm cranky. Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I didn't have the real thing. How could you even know?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You married a dying man. You thought six months, a year, it'll be tough. But then I'll recover and I'll have the rest of my life. It's like willingly getting the flu or joining the Peace Corps. Short term.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Wow, you nailed it. It was basically like a wasted weekend.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The sacrifices you made were huge. But they were at the height of your love for him. Commitment is only commitment because it has no expiration date. You stand next to someone and watch them floss for 30 years like my parents have, then ask for sacrifices. That's how you know the real thing. Cameron, I wasn't criticizing you. People who avoid commitment are people who know what a big thing it is.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: This isn’t right.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: CIPA can’t cause this much degeneration.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A few nerve fibers we teased out of the center had some insulation left. But the insulation around the bundles is stripped bare.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Means damage must be coming from the outside in.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which means it’s secondary demyelination. Which means the source is somewhere else. Which tells us it’s not a nerve disease means it’s something systemic that’s affecting the nerves. Which mean we need to… Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Kid’s mom is finally out of surgery

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ll be right back.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Hannah should see her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, immediately after we’re done chatting about saving her life. Most likely causes are metabolic.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: They found brain swelling. They’re prepping her mother for another surgery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Again, so what? Get a nurse to take the kid. There are more than sixty different metabolic conditions that could account for what she’s got. There are only three of you guys.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She’s scared.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She should be. She’ll die if we don’t diagnose her.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So, diagnose her.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Mom.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: How… How bad is it? Are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I’m okay, mom. I’ll get better. I always get better.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: Are you checking yourself? Your temperature?

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Mom, could you just let it go. You shouldn’t be worrying.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: Baby, I’m sorry. I should have seen that car coming.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: No. Mom, I did this to myself. I screwed up. You were right. You were right and I was wrong.

utterance.speaker: Cynthia
utterance.content: No. No.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I shouldn’t have gone out on the ice. And I shouldn’t have fallen down. And I shouldn’t have made you rush me to an E.R. for the tenth time this year. Mom? Mom?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You okay? We’re gonna have to take her back to surgery. Hannah, your BP is way up. We need to get you some rest.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: My hand’s wet.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re crying.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: I can’t cry. Oh. My head’s killing me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, what does the pain tell us?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No tingling, no itching. So we can rule out…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It tells us nothing. It wasn’t physical pain, it was emotional.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exactly. What were they doing when she got the headache?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Saying goodbye.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You said they were arguing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: They weren’t really arguing. She was just frustrated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What were they arguing about?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Whose fault it was.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Peripheral neuropathy, fever and intermittent paranoia. Lots of metabolic conditions can explain those things. But what if we add guilt?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Guilt as a symptom?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Alzheimer’s can cause euphoria. Pain causes depression. And B12 deficiency causes guilt along with all that other stuff.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If she felt guilty, she wouldn’t be making her mother’s life miserable. She wouldn’t be getting into fights, getting arrested…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maybe she’s fighting because she feels guilty. She’s showing her mom she can take stupid risks and still be safe. Means her mom can let go.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Which is rational. If guilt is a symptom it’s caused by the illness, not by a thought process. And it would have to be new.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: A couple of years ago she was a model student.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: This is pointless. If the headache was caused by the illness, it means she has a B12 deficiency. If it’s just because she was sad, it’s meaningless. How the hell do we test for that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We don’t. Give her a shot of B12. If she gets better, I was right.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We already did. The E.R. gave her B12 when she was admitted, part of a multivitamin supplement. Apparently she’s just sad.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are you still here?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Trying to get a couple of patients into a drug trial. Paperwork’s due tomorrow. Why are you here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I still haven’t figured out why.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, I meant here. In my office.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just dumped a cool B12 theory. Moved on to leukemia.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Very pedestrian.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not happy. Her white blood cell count was low. But the ones she’s got… Just a whole lot of eosinophils.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The immunoglobulin E level’s borderline. If you want to be one hundred percent sure, check the bone marrow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Team’s doing a biopsy right now. So it turns out, the weird lawyer knew that she used to be a man.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And he’s cool with that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Turns out that his previous girlfriend also used to be a man.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ho, ho.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Is it possible for you to just watch me eat. Or do you get some primeval thrill out of beating the other hunters to the food. See you later.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: You still haven’t figured out that I don’t need sedation.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s so you don’t move during the procedure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is that nitrous? What are you, trying to kill her? You gave her nitrous during the EEG. That’s what made this thing rear it’s ugly head.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What thing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: B12 deficiency.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Are you having déjà vu? We’ve had this conversation. She was given B12. She didn’t get better.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because someone else ate it. Get an abdominal MRI.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: What? What are you doing? Don’t touch me. Don’t touch me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See. There she goes. Another paranoid delusion. She’s going downhill. Forget the MRI. We need an O.R.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Leave me alone.

utterance.speaker: Female Surgeon
utterance.content: Occupied.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Her hernia can wait.

utterance.speaker: Hannah
utterance.content: Help. They’re trying to kill me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay. You can either believe that we really are trying to kill her… or you can assume that she’s suffering from a medical condition. Seeing as this is a hospital and we’re all dressed like doctors and there are easier ways to kill somebody…

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: Bev, help them.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m going to need iodine, scalpel numbers 10 and 15, forceps and a largish salad bowl. Okay. Hold her down. Come on, weenies, she’s in a cast. Swab. Fifteen.

utterance.speaker: Surgeon
utterance.content: You’re not going to anesthetize her?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax. It’s just a magic trick. She’s faking it. We’re not falling for it this time. Okay, keep that retracted. Forceps. Lake fishing can be fun. It can bring the generations together. If you don’t cook that trout or perch well, you’ll be giving room and board to this fellow. By free board, I mean all the B12 you can take in.

utterance.speaker: Bev
utterance.content: I could have a tapeworm in me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not likely. You’d be in a lot of pain.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s gotta be twenty five feet long.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Damn. World record’s over sixty.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hannah. Wake up. Somebody here to see you. She’s got limited motion on her left side. You might have to take care of her for a while. Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa. You don’t feel it, but you’re about to rip your stitches out. Take care of yourself. Then you can take care of her.

utterance.speaker: Wendy
utterance.content: You haven’t gone home.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sorry I screwed up Valentine’s Day.

utterance.speaker: Wendy
utterance.content: I’m dating a doctor. I’d be an idiot to expect anything else.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I did get you a gift. MGH – best teaching hospital in Boston. Wanna be a nurse practitioner, that’s as good as it gets. I made a few calls and, you’re in if you want in.

utterance.speaker: Wendy
utterance.content: This is why you’ve been helping me get my surgical hours for accreditation.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I thought you wanted…

utterance.speaker: Wendy
utterance.content: Stupid. You’ve got ten feet of personal space around you. I step forward, you step back.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’ve shared a lot of things with you.

utterance.speaker: Wendy
utterance.content: Which is why you’re breaking up with me. You can’t stand to be close.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wendy, you think I’ll stay with you because you’re angry with me?

utterance.speaker: Wendy
utterance.content: I’m upset. Because I care. Only you’d expect an argument to be rational. You and that ass boss of yours.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You could ask her for the spinal nerve.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s got no reason to give it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She owes you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The hospital will send her a bill.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m just saying, if you wanna do it, do it while her B12 is still low. Guilt can be your friend. Breakfast?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Happy Valentine's Day.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: A holiday that only applies to people who are already paired up. For everyone else it's Wednesday.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Wow. Thank you for that dash of cold water.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Don't get me wrong. I still think true love's out there it's just very far away. Possibly in another galaxy. We may need to develop faster than light travel before we can make contact. So I'm thinking we should have sex.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That makes sense.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Despite the wisdom of pop songs. there's no point in putting our lives on hold 'til love comes along. We're both healthy and busy people. We work together so it's convenient.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Like microwave pizza?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And of all the people I work with, you're the one I'm least likely to fall in love with.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Like… microwave pizza.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The point here is to make things simpler, not more complicated. Someday there'll be time to get serious about someone. Meanwhile, we already had sex once and didn't get weird about it. So…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I get it. I get it. So, what if I'm offended by your judgement.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Then you're not the man I'm looking for.
